author: bridge-bot
content:
<mratsim> We had a discussion during ProgCrypto of the impact of Verkle Tries for zkEVM.

Discussion with at least:

- <@427491045308235776>
- @adietrichs 
- Onur Kilic
- @dankrad 
- Mary Maller
- @CPerezz 

And I'm missing some names.

Basically, introducing the BLS precompiles (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2537, note they might need a refresh) could significantly ease their proving cost if zkEVMs switch to BLS12-381 curves.

Also some of the considerations that existed in the past:
- not enough production grade BLS12-381 implementations
- EVM384 (or eWASM or Weierstrudel) obsoleting the need of cryptography precompiles

are not true anymore.

Furthermore the precompile has been implemented but not activated since Berlin hardfork (except for OpenEthereum who activated it by mistake and took down Etherscan for 36h) (re @CarlBeek: Although it was a major pitty we didn't get to host an in person RollCall in Istanbul, I had many great discussions and hope you did too.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<shemnon> EVM384 has been supplanted by EVMMAX (EIP-6690 Modular Arithmetic Extension), which is built off of EOF currently, so that is the current alternate to more precompiles.  Proof of concepts have been done for BN254 and BLS12-381 ecadd as of devconnect.

However consider that 2537 was almost in berlin all clients have some (possibly rusty) code that handles it.  Likley it needs a gas cost revisit.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<djaganche> Some in-production zkEVMs(PSE, scroll and taiko to my knowledge) need bls12-381 to verify the proof made by pairing(or any eliptic curve field technique) proof system which uses bls12-381, and it's currently very expensive to verify that without bls12-381 precompile, that's why they use bn254 in their proof system althought bn254 is not considered safe.

Reg others like FRI with small fields (risc0, starkware(kakarot), BaseFold paper, etc. seems that those are the most performant solutions but there are some security tradeoffs when making such a zkEVM since you need to configure some parameters in FRI in order to make verifier contract on L1 cheap enough. I'm not super sure about this statement but that's how i understand it (re @gakonst: WDYM zkEVMs switching to bls12-381? what about the non-pairing based zk vm designs?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <mratsim> They STARK -> Groth16 -> verification on-chain via BN254 pairing, Risc0 style. (re @gakonst: WDYM zkEVMs switching to bls12-381? what about the non-pairing based zk vm designs?)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<mratsim> But even them have dedicated circuits for costly functions like keccak. Some call that syscalls, some call that circuits, some call that coprocessors.

I don't know enough to tell if that enables new potential for proof composition/cost reduction.

content:
<icemelon> verification is definitely expensive withou bls12-381 precopmile. proving cost with bls12-381 and recursion / aggregation cost will also become higher than bn254 because the curve field operation has more bits (381 vs 254). we need to do more performance benchmark to understand the overhead of switching over to bls12-381 curve (re @djaganche: Some in-production zkEVMs(PSE, scroll and taiko to my knowledge) need bls12-381 to verify the proof made by pairing(or any eliptic curve field technique) proof system which uses bls12-381, and it's currently very expensive to verify that without bls12-381 precompile, that's why they use bn254 in their proof system althought bn254 is not considered safe.

author: bridge-bot
content: <gakonst> Yeah. Binius inverts the “keccak is expensive” paradigm on the head by making bitwise operations a first class citizen. It’s IMO most promising Type-1 zkEVM candidate proof system atm due to that. Keen to see how things play out with improvements in coming months for recursion. See Justin Thaler’s post on the nuance.: https://a16zcrypto.com/posts/article/a-technical-faq-on-lasso-jolt-and-recent-advancements-in-snark-design/#section--12

author: bridge-bot
content:
<mratsim> that would help a lot with keccak but not scalar mul.

Another concern is that there used to be debates between binary fields and prime fields to build elliptic curves and cryptographers choose prime fields because less chance of surprise findings breaking everything (looking at you isogenies).

That said, it looks very interesting, especially for consensus (see https://ethresear.ch/t/signature-merging-for-large-scale-consensus/17386/2 ) (re @e_nyc: Worth a read https://www.ulvetanna.io/news/binius-hardware-optimized-snark)
